## Brookhaven FACE Program
<hr>
<br/>

<IMG STYLE="position:absolute; TOP:175px; LEFT:650px; WIDTH:375px; HEIGHT:500px" SRC="images/co2hypo.jpg">

<div style="float: left; width: 55%;">

* **Terrestrial biosphere responds to rising [CO<sub>2</sub>]**
      + fundamental role in rate of global change
      + photosynthesis removes CO<sub>2</sub> from the atmosphere
      + respiration by plants and heterotrophs add it back.
      
<br/>

* **Plants respond to rising [CO<sub>2</sub>] through ↑ photosynthesis and ↓ transpiration**
      + what greenhouse experiments tell us

<br/>
      
* **Techonology to grow plants in the field at a controlled [CO<sub>2</sub>] under open-air conditions** 
      + better estimate of plant and ecosystem response to a high CO<sub>2</sub> world
      
</div>

## Free-air CO<sub>2</sub> enrichment experiments (FACE)
<hr>
<br/>

<div style="float: right; width: 55%;">

* **Circular plots surrounded by a ring of pipes**
      + release ambient or enriched CO<sub>2</sub>
      + @ vertical intervals through plant canopy. 

<br/>

* **Wind direction/velocity and [CO<sub>2</sub>] are measured at the center of each plot**
      + computers adjust CO<sub>2</sub> flow rate to maintain target
      + pipes on the upwind side of the plots release CO<sub>2</sub>

<br/>
      
 * **Utilized with some variationss in numerous large-scale experiments**
    + up to 30m diameter plots
    + vegetation up to 25 meters

</div>

<IMG STYLE="position:absolute; TOP:175px; LEFT:65px; WIDTH:400px; HEIGHT:500px" SRC="images/design.png">

## Brookhaven National Lab: FACE Specs
<hr>
<br/>

<div style="float: right; width: 50%;">

* **Circular systems designed to allow open-air exposures to CO<sub>2</sub>, sulfur dioxide, nitrogen oxides, and ozone**
    + uniform exposures of gases to large plots
    
<br/>

* **Liquid CO<sub>2</sub> is piped from storage tanks to heat exchangers to vaporize the CO2**
       + CO<sub>2</sub> is typically obtained as a by-product fertilizer manufacturing 
       
<br/>

* **Gaseous CO<sub>2</sub> is channeled through pipes by pressure regulators to each FACE plot**
    + 24 to 32 vertical standing vent pipes for emitting CO<sub>2</sub> 

</div>

<IMG STYLE="position:absolute; TOP:250px; LEFT:100px; WIDTH:400px; HEIGHT:300px" SRC="images/liquid.jpg">

## Advantages of FACE
<hr>
<br/>

<div style="float: left; width: 55%;">

* **Investigation of undisturbed ecosystems**
      + light, temperature, wind & precipitation
      + interactions with pathogens and insects
      + natural or agriculture systems

<br/>

* **Integrated measurements of plant and ecosystem processes simultaneously**
    + avoids problems with edge effects
    + plants studied throughout life cycle 
    + trees have space to develop to canopy closure

<br/>

* **Additional treatments**
    + Ozone
    + Nitrogen
</div>

<IMG STYLE="position:absolute; TOP:250px; LEFT:625px; WIDTH:400px; HEIGHT:300px" SRC="images/grasslandface.jpg">

## BIOCON: Minnesota, USA
<hr>

<div style="float: left; width: 60%;">

* **Secondary successional old field after vegetation cleared**
      + glacial out wash sandplain 
      + nitrogen limited site

<br/>

* **371 plots (2x2m) arranged in six 20m rings**
      + each ring has 61-63 plots
      + 16 species of herbaceous perennial prairie species

<br/>

* **biodiversity, N, CO<sub>2</sub> and H<sub>2</sub>0 manipulated**
      + elevated CO<sub>2</sub> in 3 rings (560 ppm)
      + subplot rain removal via portable rain shelters
      + warming with soil rod and infrared lamp technology
      + 1/2 of plots receive N addition @ 2x deposition
</div>
<IMG STYLE="position:absolute; TOP:250px; LEFT:650px; WIDTH:400px; HEIGHT:300px" SRC="images/biocon.jpg">

## SoyFACE: U.Illinois
<hr>
<br/>

* **32-ha farm with 20m plots**
    + eCO<sub>2</sub> plots
    + elevated O<sub>3</sub> plots
    + warming subplots (+3.5°C)

<br/>
<br/>

* **Research questions:**
<br/>
1. What yield and quality changes will result with rising CO<sub>2</sub>, temperature, drought stress and ozone?
2. What genotypes and genes may be exploited to ↑ yield and maintain quality under future conditions?
3. Will soil quality be degraded, and how can this be alleviated?
4. Will rates of soil carbon deposition ↑, and what value might this have in terms of carbon credits?
5. How will eCO<sub>2</sub>, temperature, drought stress and ozone impact insect and pathogens?

## DUKE - Key findings
<hr>
<br/>
<br/>

<div style="float: left; width: 55%;">

* **Photosynthesis by canopy foliage ↑ up to 50 %**
    + litterfall ↑ in eCO<sub>2</sub> and litter layer ↑

<br/>

* **Minimal change in the SOM from eCO<sub>2</sub>**

<br/>

* **Stimulation of NPP by eCO<sub>2</sub> persisted** 
    + biomass + 27% in eCO<sub>2</sub> plots
    + evidence of N limitation started
</div>

## Oak Ridge - Key Findings
<hr>
<br/>
<br/>

<div style="float: left; width: 55%;">

* **Enhancement of NPP not sustained via N cycle feedbacks**
    + N availability declined faster under eCO<sub>2</sub>
    + lower soil microbial biomass under eCO<sub>2</sub>

<br/>

* **Fine-root production was stimulated by eCO<sub>2</sub>**
    + more deep fine roots
    + resulting in more C added to the soil system.
    
<br/>

* **Carbon storage in the soil ↑ in elevated CO<sub>2</sub>**
    + including in protected forms
</div>

<IMG STYLE="position:absolute; TOP:250px; LEFT:615px; WIDTH:400px; HEIGHT:300px" SRC="images/nppornl.gif">

## BIOCON: Grassland Findings
<hr>
<br/>
<br/>
<br/>

<div style="float: left; width: 55%;">

* **eCO<sub>2</sub> had modest effects on species richness**

<br/>

* **Diversity loss due to N enrichment under aCO<sub>2</sub>**
    + diversity suppressed by N effects on productivity
    + soil solution N, soil moisture & root C:N

<br/>

* **eCO<sub>2</sub> amlieorated this diversity loss**
    + interaction treatments
</div>

<IMG STYLE="position:absolute; TOP:175px; LEFT:650px; WIDTH300px; HEIGHT:500px" SRC="images/biocon2.gif">

## SOY FACE: Key Findings
<hr>
<br/>

<div style="float: left; width: 55%;">

* **Smaller than expected ↑ in photosynthesis/biomass for soybeans at eCO<sub>2</sub>**
    + warming also offset biomass increases via eCO<sub>2</sub>

<br/>

* **Low stomatal limitation, ↑ respiration & photosynthetic acclimation muted response to eCO<sub>2</sub> & temperature**

<br/>

* **O<sub>3</sub> fumigation reduced photosynthesis**

<br/>

* **Overall, soybeans were less nutritous**
      + decreased Fe & Zn 
</div> 

<IMG STYLE="position:absolute; TOP:250px; LEFT:610px; WIDTH:400px; HEIGHT:300px" SRC="images/soy2.jpg">

## Synthesis Results from FACE
<hr>
<br/>
<br/>
<br/>

<div style="float: left; width: 55%;">

* **eCO<sub>2</sub> ↑ leaf photosynthesis by 31% across sites and species**

<br/>

* **Stomatal conductance ↓ by 20% with growth at eCO<sub>2</sub> across 40 species**
    + low N and drought exacerbated the ↓ in g<sub>s</sub>

<br/>

* **Plant water use efficiency ↑ under eCO<sub>2</sub> ~50%**
</div>

<IMG STYLE="position:absolute; TOP:250px; LEFT:650px; WIDTH:400px; HEIGHT:400" SRC="images/synthesis.gif">


## Synthesis Results from FACE
<hr>
<br/>

<div style="float: left; width: 55%;">

* **Growth and aboveground biomass ↑ with eCO<sub>2</sub>**
      + ~20% enhancement
      + response varied between species, growing seasons and experimental conditions 
      + trees > crops > grasses
      
<br/>

* **Allocation to wood and structure ↑ woody plants under eCO<sub>2</sub>**
      + taller plants
      + larger stem diameter
      + increased branching and leaf #
      
<br/>
  
* **Nutrient limitation muted the aboveground enhancement**
</div>

<IMG STYLE="position:absolute; TOP:250px; LEFT:650px; WIDTH:400px; HEIGHT:400" SRC="images/synthesis3.gif">

## FACE: Crops
<hr>
<br/>
<br/>


<div style="float: left; width: 55%;">

* **Crop yield ↑ by only ~ 17%**
    + lower than previous estimates 

<br/>

* **Cotton, a woody crop, showed most yield enhancement in eCO<sub>2</sub>**

<br/>

* **Site conditions modulated eCO<sub>2</sub> response**
    + no yield increase in wet conditions
    + 28% increase in dry conditions
    + Low N fertilization  eliminated any yield response
</div>

<IMG STYLE="position:absolute; TOP:250px; LEFT:650px; WIDTH:400px; HEIGHT:400" SRC="images/synthesis4.gif">

## Ecological Lessons from FACE Experiments
<hr>
<br/>

* **Time =  is highest importance in consideration of C cycling**
    + life stage, functional type, canopy closure
    + how long to reach equilibrium?

<br/>

* **Different C allocation patterns of extra C taken up**
    + allocation of plant C among SOM pools determines ecosystem C fate
    + exudation, litter fragmentation, priming, soil aggregation & microbial activity important

<br/>

* **Some evidence of N limitation reducing the eCO<sub>2</sub> response**

<br/>

* **Plant community structure influences ecosystem response to eCO<sub>2</sub>**
    + composition more important to ecosystem responses than individual species.

## Sweed FACE
<hr>
<br/>

<div style="float: left; width: 45%;">

* **Proposed site in 35‐yr old closed‐canopy stand of mature Scots pine**
      + hemiboreal zone of southern Sweden
      + stand noncommercial thinning before canopy closure
      + now unmanaged

      + warming/extended growing season promoting C release?

## EUC FACE
<hr>
<br/>

<div style="float: left; width: 55%;">

* **Sites in a mature native Australian woodland**
    + Cumberland Forest is now down to just 6% (Sydney expansion)
    + open and grassy with native and introduced grasses

<br/>

* **3 eCO<sub>2</sub> + 3 aCO<sub>2</sub> rings**
    + eCO<sub>2</sub> 'ramped up' over a year
    + Nutrient and water limited forest

<br/>

* **Designed to minimise environmental footprint**
    + no concrete in the forest 
    + rings are raised so that animals can move freely
    + access by raised footpaths only
 </div>
